column8:
The Brabham BT46 was a Formula One racing car, designed by Gordon Murray for the Brabham team, owned by Bernie Ecclestone, for the 1978 Formula One season. The “B” variant of the car, also known as the fan car, was introduced at the 1978 Swedish Grand Prix as a counter to the dominant ground effect Lotus 79.
The BT46B generated an immense level of downforce by means of a fan, claimed to be for increased cooling, but which also extracted air from beneath the car. The car only raced once in this configuration in the Formula One World Championship; Niki Lauda winning the 1978 Swedish Grand Prix at Anderstorp. The car was withdrawn before it could race again and the concept declared illegal by the FIA. The BT46B therefore preserves a 100% winning record.
column21: The Brabham BT46 was a Formula One racing car, designed by Gordon Murray for the Brabham team, owned by Bernie Ecclestone, for the 1978 Formula One season.

column8: Ever since I can remember I had a fixation with dinosaurs and with such films as Land Before Time and Jurassic Park who wouldn't be. I even wanted to be a paleontologist when I grew up. But that didn't quite turn out for me.
column21: Just about everybody has been obsessed with Dinosaurs at some point, so fascinating are they. This design, part of a series, aims to express that admiration.

column8:
Greek philosophers Alcmaeon and Pythagoras labelled the brain ‘as the organ of the mind’.


Intelligence and creativity are the two capacities of the human brain that make us different from the brain of primitive animals. It allows us to solve problems, grasp the abstract, analyse, and imagine. But exactly how is something neuroscientists continue to be amazed by.
column21: An amazingly detailed design admiring that organ which is more complex than anything else in the known universe: the human brain.
